items.title: Khawaja misses out on century as Jacks gets first Ashes wicket
items.summary: Will Jacks gets his first Ashes wicket as he removes Usman Khawaja for 82, with the batter caught by Josh Tongue in the deep, leaving Australia 185-5 on day one of the third Ashes Test in Adelaide.

items.title: 65 Winter Cocktails That Will Get You Feeling Festive
items.summary: Your heart will definitely grow three sizes after trying our spiked hot chocolate.

items.title: Two wickets in three balls as Archer removes Labuschagne and Green
items.summary: England's Jofra Archer gets two wickets in three balls, removing Marnus Labuschagne and Cameron Green in the first over after lunch as Australia fall to 94-4 on day one of the third Ashes Test in Adelaide.

items.summary: Jofra Archer removes Jake Weatherald for 18 as England make an early breakthrough against Australia, leaving the home side 33-1 on day one of the third Test in Adelaide.

items.title: 'Walking away a great' - Crawford retires from boxing
items.summary: Five-weight world champion Terence Crawford says he is "walking away as a great with nothing else left to prove" after announcing his retirement from boxing at the age of 38.

items.title: 'What a stunner' - Crawley takes brilliant catch to remove Head
items.summary: England's Zak Crawley produces a brilliant one-handed catch to remove Travis Head for 10 as Australia fall to 33-2 on day one of the third Ashes Test in Adelaide.

items.title: Australia and England pay tribute to victims of Bondi beach shooting
items.summary: Before the third Ashes Test in Adelaide, Australia and England players observe a moment's silence to pay respect to the victims of the Bondi Beach shooting which took place on Sunday.

items.title: Jaguar Type 00 EV First Ride: It Still Looks Odd, but Itâ€™s Seriously Quick
items.summary: We took a hair-raising trip around a track in the final four-door GT version of Jaguar's polarizing relaunch concept car. Is just might be good enough to end the British brand's abysmal run of luck.

items.title: Australia's Smith out of third Test with illness
items.summary: Usman Khawaja, who was left out after losing his place after experiencing back spasms in the first Test, replaces Steve Smith in the Australia XI in Adelaide.

items.title: 'Rediscovering joy' - Cardiff pride in Chelsea defeat
items.summary: Brian Barry-Murphy takes pride - and a desire to be at this level again - as his Cardiff City side lose to Chelsea in the EFL Cup quarter-finals.

items.title: Maresca 'happy' at Chelsea & 'in love' with squad
items.summary: Chelsea's Enzo Maresca says he is "happy" and "falling more in love with the players", days after saying he experienced "the worst 48 hours" of his tenure.

items.title: 'Felt like humiliation' - Egypt reacts to Salah's Liverpool row
items.summary: Mohamed Salah's Liverpool row felt like "humiliation" for Egyptian fans, who are rallying behind their star man before the Africa Cup of Nations begins.

items.title: Winning start for Price at PDC World Championship
items.summary: Gerwyn Price begins his bid for a second PDC world title with a convincing straight-set win against Adam Gawlas in the first round.

items.title: We Tried & Upgraded All Of Joanna Gaines's New Store-Bought Baked Goods

items.title: The 'eerie' parallels between Mahomes & Brady after ACL tear
items.summary: The Whole 10 Yards panel discusses the "eerie" similarities between the careers of Patrick Mahomes and Tom Brady, after the Chiefs quarterback tore his ACL in Sunday's defeat by the Chargers.

items.title: Five clubs in Semenyo chase - Wednesday's gossip
items.summary: Five Premier League clubs in the frame to sign Bournemouth winger Antoine Semenyo, Everton interested in Middlesbrough's Hayden Hackney, Aston Villa plan Youri Tielemans contract talks, plus more.

items.title: Green becomes most expensive overseas IPL player
items.summary: Kolkata Knight Riders sign Australia all-rounder Cameron Green for 25.2 crore (Â£2.1m) for next year's Indian Premier League.

Dembele wins Fifa Best men's player of the year

items.title: Bonmati named Fifa Best women's player of the year

items.title: James Webb telescope spots 'monster stars' leaking nitrogen in the early universe â€” and they could help solve a major mystery
items.summary: Researchers using the James Webb Space Telescope spotted huge stars leaking nitrogen in an early galaxy, hinting that such 'monster stars' might have been the source of ancient supermassive black holes.

items.title: Einstein was right: Time ticks faster on Mars, posing new challenges for future missions
items.summary: Clocks on Mars tick faster by about 477 microseconds each Earth day, a new study suggests. This difference is significantly more than that for our moon, posing potential challenges for future crewed missions.

items.title: Breakthrough 3D wiring architecture enables 10,000-qubit quantum processors
items.summary: The novel 3D wiring architecture and chip fabrication method enable quantum processing units containing 10,000 qubits to fit in a smaller space than today's 100-qubit chips.

New models, efforts for early detection and better therapies may help change pancreatic cancerâ€™s aggressive course.
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03941-5 New models, efforts for early detection and better therapies may help change pancreatic cancerâ€™s aggressive course.

items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03949-x Why some institutions are betting on technology to stay relevant.

items.title: Exposing a silent cancer
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03942-4

Pancreatic cancer is one of the deadliest malignancies, and it is increasingly occurring in young people â€” especially women. An uptick in research fundinâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03942-4 Pancreatic cancer is one of the deadliest malignancies, and it is increasingly occurring in young people â€” especially women. An uptick in research funding is a welcome development in the push to transform treatment.

items.title: Fasting boosts breast cancer therapy efficacy via glucocorticoid activation
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09869-0

Beneficial effects of fasting combined with endocrine therapy for oestrogen receptor-Î±-expressing breast cancers can be recapitulated using exogenous gluâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09869-0 Beneficial effects of fasting combined with endocrine therapy for oestrogen receptor-Î±-expressing breast cancers can be recapitulated using exogenous glucocorticoid receptor ligands instead of fasting to reduce harmful effects.

items.title: The influence of short-lived halogens on atmospheric chemistry and climate
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09753-x

A Review of the impacts of short-lived halogens on air quality and climate identifies gaps in our knowledge of short-lived halogen emissions, chemistry, â€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09753-x A Review of the impacts of short-lived halogens on air quality and climate identifies gaps in our knowledge of short-lived halogen emissions, chemistry, and the environmental and climate impacts.

items.title: Quantifying grain boundary deformation mechanisms in small-grained metals
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09800-7

Experimental observations in small-grained polycrystals suggest a new concept of considering metallic grain boundaries not as defects but as separate defâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09800-7 Experimental observations in small-grained polycrystals suggest a new concept of considering metallic grain boundaries not as defects but as separate defect-containing lattices, providing a potential explanation for the deformation behaviour of nanocrystalline metals.

items.title: Gene-drive-capable mosquitoes suppress patient-derived malaria in Tanzania
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09685-6

Engineering of local Anopheles gambiae under containment enables the generation of a transgenic strain equipped with non-autonomous gene drive capabilitiâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09685-6 Engineering of local Anopheles gambiae under containment enables the generation of a transgenic strain equipped with non-autonomous gene drive capabilities that robustly inhibits genetically diverse Plasmodium falciparum isolates obtained from naturally infected children.

items.title: Erythropoietin receptor on cDC1s dictates immune tolerance
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09824-z

The tolerogenic activity of type 1 conventional dendritic cells (cDC1s) is determined by EPOR, which is preferentially expressed in cDC1s and induces antâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09824-z The tolerogenic activity of type 1 conventional dendritic cells (cDC1s) is determined by EPOR, which is preferentially expressed in cDC1s and induces antigen-specific FOXP3-expressing regulatory T cells.

items.title: Human gut M cells resemble dendritic cells and present gluten antigen
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09829-8

An intestinal organoid model recapitulates human microfold (M) cell function and transcriptomic profiling and biochemical assays demonstrate that M cellsâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09829-8 An intestinal organoid model recapitulates human microfold (M) cell function and transcriptomic profiling and biochemical assays demonstrate that M cells uptake and present antigens to the immune system via the class II major histocompatibility complex.

items.title: Cross-regulation of [2Feâ€“2S] cluster synthesis by ferredoxin-2 and frataxin
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09822-1

A finely balanced ratio of ferredoxin-2 (FDX2) and frataxin (FXN) is essential for the synthesis of ironâ€“sulfur clusters, and interventions targeting thiâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09822-1 A finely balanced ratio of ferredoxin-2 (FDX2) and frataxin (FXN) is essential for the synthesis of ironâ€“sulfur clusters, and interventions targeting this ratio could provide a way to treat related diseases, such as Friedreichâ€™s ataxia.

items.title: Sterilization and contraception increase lifespan across vertebrates
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09836-9

Data collected from zoos and aquariums worldwide show that hormonal contraception or permanent surgical sterilization in mammals increase life expectancyâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09836-9 Data collected from zoos and aquariums worldwide show that hormonal contraception or permanent surgical sterilization in mammals increase life expectancy, with different mechanisms in males and females.

items.title: Observation of deuteron and antideuteron formation from resonance-decay nucleons
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09775-5

The ALICE Collaboration provides details on the microscopic mechanism that ends up creating antideuteron in high-energy protonâ€“proton collisions at the Lâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09775-5 The ALICE Collaboration provides details on the microscopic mechanism that ends up creating antideuteron in high-energy protonâ€“proton collisions at the Large Hadron Collider.

items.title: Hot droughts in the Amazon provide a window to a future hypertropical climate
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09728-y

Thirty years of forest demographic data, combined with recent ecophysiological measurements, reveal that intense Amazon droughts sharply increase tree moâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09728-y Thirty years of forest demographic data, combined with recent ecophysiological measurements, reveal that intense Amazon droughts sharply increase tree mortality once soil moisture falls below a threshold, and that these hot droughts will become more frequent and intense as Earth warms towards hypertropical conditions.

items.title: A direct role for a mitochondrial targeting sequence in signalling stress
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09834-x

Cells can sense mitochondrial damage through signalling via an unimported mitochondrial targeting sequence.
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09834-x Cells can sense mitochondrial damage through signalling via an unimported mitochondrial targeting sequence.

items.title: Neutrophils preserve energy storage in sympathetically activated adipocytes
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09839-6

Neutrophil-derived IL-1Î² has a role in preserving lipid stores during metabolic stress.
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09839-6 Neutrophil-derived IL-1Î² has a role in preserving lipid stores during metabolic stress.

items.title: An RNA splicing system that excises DNA transposons from animal mRNAs
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09853-8

A new type of mRNA splicing mechanism discovered in Caenorhabditis elegans that detects and removes inverted repeats also occurs in human cells, thereby â€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09853-8 A new type of mRNA splicing mechanism discovered in Caenorhabditis elegans that detects and removes inverted repeats also occurs in human cells, thereby providing another strategy to protect against the negative effects of transposable elements.

items.title: Uncovering the role of LINE-1 in the evolution of lung adenocarcinoma
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09825-y

Lung adenocarcinomas bearing the ID2 mutational signature display increased LINE-1 retrotransposon activity, which contributes to their fast evolutionaryâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09825-y Lung adenocarcinomas bearing the ID2 mutational signature display increased LINE-1 retrotransposon activity, which contributes to their fast evolutionary dynamics and aggressive phenotype.

items.title: Somatic evolution following cancer treatment in normal tissue
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09792-4

High-depth sequencing of non-cancerous tissue from patients with metastatic cancer reveals single-base mutational signatures of alcohol, smoking and cancâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09792-4 High-depth sequencing of non-cancerous tissue from patients with metastatic cancer reveals single-base mutational signatures of alcohol, smoking and cancer treatments, and reveals how exogenous factors, including cancer therapies, affect somatic cell evolution.

items.title: Protected area management has significant spillover effects on vegetation
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09837-8

Analysis of effect sizes of vegetation spillovers from protected areas in Australia shows that 71% of over 3,063 analysed protected areas had a positive â€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09837-8 Analysis of effect sizes of vegetation spillovers from protected areas in Australia shows that 71% of over 3,063 analysed protected areas had a positive spillover effect, and that these effects covary with protected area management type.

items.title: Laser-based conversion electron MÃ¶ssbauer spectroscopy of <sup>229</sup>ThO<sub>2</sub>
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09776-4

Laser-induced conversion electron MÃ¶ssbauer spectroscopy, which detects electrons emitted by 229Th nuclei in a thin ThO2 sample excited by vacuum ultraviâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09776-4 Laser-induced conversion electron MÃ¶ssbauer spectroscopy, which detects electrons emitted by 229Th nuclei in a thin ThO2 sample excited by vacuum ultraviolet light, is demonstrated, opening the possibility of a conversion-electron-based nuclear clock.

items.title: Agonists for cytosolic bacterial receptor ALPK1 induce antitumour immunity
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09828-9

The ALPK1 agonist UDSP-Hep stimulates tumour-cell antigen presentation, macrophageâ€“DC cross-priming and differentiation of protective memory T cells.
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09828-9 The ALPK1 agonist UDSP-Hep stimulates tumour-cell antigen presentation, macrophageâ€“DC cross-priming and differentiation of protective memory T cells.

items.title: Causal modelling of gene effects from regulators to programs to traits
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09866-3

Approaches combining genetic association and Perturb-seq data that link genetic variants to functional programs to traits are described.
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09866-3 Approaches combining genetic association and Perturb-seq data that link genetic variants to functional programs to traits are described.

items.title: Mutations in mitochondrial ferredoxin FDX2 suppress frataxin deficiency
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09821-2

A forward genetic screen in Caenorhabditis elegans reveals that decreased levels of the ferredoxin FDX2 suppress the loss of frataxin in worms and in micâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09821-2 A forward genetic screen in Caenorhabditis elegans reveals that decreased levels of the ferredoxin FDX2 suppress the loss of frataxin in worms and in mice by relief of FDX2 inhibition of frataxin-stimulated NFS1 activity.

items.title: Gut micro-organisms associated with health, nutrition and dietary interventions
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09854-7

Comprehensive large-scale studies of multi-national populations identified microbiome species consistently associated with favourable and unfavourable heâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09854-7 Comprehensive large-scale studies of multi-national populations identified microbiome species consistently associated with favourable and unfavourable health markers, informing future studies of the human gut microbiome and its association with diet and cardiometabolic conditions.

items.title: Pancreatic cancer is evasive. Is the nervous system the reason why?
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03943-3

A growing body of research suggests tumours rely on proteins and genes that are unique to the nervous system to persist in the body.
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03943-3 A growing body of research suggests tumours rely on proteins and genes that are unique to the nervous system to persist in the body.

From lectures by avatars to entire qualifications, higher education centred around AI is just around the corner.
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03950-4 From lectures by avatars to entire qualifications, higher education centred around AI is just around the corner.

items.title: A breathalyser-style test for detecting pancreatic cancer
items.summary:

Surgeon George Hanna is developing a non-invasive test to catch one of the deadliest cancers before itâ€™s too late.
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03946-0 Surgeon George Hanna is developing a non-invasive test to catch one of the deadliest cancers before itâ€™s too late.

items.title: Is your brain tired? Researchers are discovering the roots of mental fatigue
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03974-w

Better ways to measure cognitive exhaustion could point to treatments for long COVID and other debilitating disorders.
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03974-w Better ways to measure cognitive exhaustion could point to treatments for long COVID and other debilitating disorders.

items.title: A giant catalogue of microscopic species across Denmark
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03819-6

The Microflora Danica project has catalogued the microbial diversity of environmental habitats across Denmark and established an improved taxonomic referâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03819-6 The Microflora Danica project has catalogued the microbial diversity of environmental habitats across Denmark and established an improved taxonomic reference database. As well as providing a special record of nitrogen-oxidizing microorganisms, the data set serves as a national baseline for tracking future microbial responses to factors such as land-use change and global warming.

items.title: SOS: RNA-processing mechanism rescues genes from invasive DNA
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03734-w

Transposable elements can insert into genes, disrupting protein-coding potential. Researchers discover a mode of RNA processing, â€˜SOS splicingâ€™, that proâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03734-w Transposable elements can insert into genes, disrupting protein-coding potential. Researchers discover a mode of RNA processing, â€˜SOS splicingâ€™, that provides a quick fix.

Making scents of things.

items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03944-2 Cellular, animal and computational models of the disease are providing fresh insights into biology and treatment.

The nationâ€™s regulators are attempting to match the rapid pace at which AI is evolving. That needs to become a global initiative.
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03972-y The nationâ€™s regulators are attempting to match the rapid pace at which AI is evolving. That needs to become a global initiative.

items.title: A simple slipknot for precise force control
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03829-4

The tension of conventional surgical sutures can affect wound healing and is dependent on the surgeonâ€™s experience. Imaging and simulations reveal that sâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03829-4 The tension of conventional surgical sutures can affect wound healing and is dependent on the surgeonâ€™s experience. Imaging and simulations reveal that slipknots can reproducibly store and release force, enabling precise and consistent surgical knotting without the need for electronic sensors or specialized equipment.

items.title: Nuclear clocks could use electrical signals to keep time
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03732-y

The emission of photons by excited nuclei has been explored for timekeeping and sensing, but nuclear processes that eject electrons offer practical advanâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03732-y The emission of photons by excited nuclei has been explored for timekeeping and sensing, but nuclear processes that eject electrons offer practical advantages.

items.title: Huge genetic study reveals hidden links between psychiatric conditions
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04037-w

Analysis of more than one million people shows that mental-health disorders fall into five clusters, each of them linked to a specific set of genetic varâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04037-w Analysis of more than one million people shows that mental-health disorders fall into five clusters, each of them linked to a specific set of genetic variants.

items.title: Genetically engineered mosquitoes block development of circulating malaria strains
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03577-5

The genetic engineering of mosquitoes offers a potentially transformative, self-sustaining opportunity for malaria control and elimination in Africa. By â€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03577-5 The genetic engineering of mosquitoes offers a potentially transformative, self-sustaining opportunity for malaria control and elimination in Africa. By rendering mosquitoes unable to transmit the malaria parasite, even when they bite humans, the technology provides a mosquito-based intervention to complement existing efforts.

items.title: Therapeutic vaccines can challenge pancreatic cancer before it takes hold
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03947-z

Specific protein targets and personalized vaccines have the potential to increase survival rates for the disease.
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03947-z Specific protein targets and personalized vaccines have the potential to increase survival rates for the disease.

items.title: The brainâ€™s speech centre responds to universal and specific features of language
items.summary:
Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03827-6

More than 7,000 languages are spoken around the world, but the human brain becomes highly specialized to process speech in an individualâ€™s own language. â€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03827-6 More than 7,000 languages are spoken around the world, but the human brain becomes highly specialized to process speech in an individualâ€™s own language. Recordings from human brains reveal the shared and language-specific neural mechanisms that arise in the superior temporal gyrus to achieve this feat.

items.title: Shared genetic risk in psychiatric disorders

Scientists have characterized the broad genetic patterns that are shared across 14 psychiatric disorders. Could it reframe how mental-health conditions aâ€¦
items.body: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03728-8 Scientists have characterized the broad genetic patterns that are shared across 14 psychiatric disorders. Could it reframe how mental-health conditions are diagnosed?

items.title: 'It felt like God's hand on my brain' - the day England were humbled by teenager
items.summary: BBC Sport's From The Ashes series concludes with the inside story of Ashton Agar's record-breaking introduction to Test cricket as a 19-year-old batting at number 11.

items.title: The great number nine decline - where have England's strikers gone?
items.summary: BBC Sport takes an in-depth look at why England lack centre-forward options behind Harry Kane - a far cry from when the likes of Les Ferdinand only won 17 caps.
